B002JVWR9U|5.0|\\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is the latest addition to a delightfully growing genre of gothic romance based on vampire lore. Playing like a teenage/young adult version of \\"True Blood,\\" the first season of \\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is engaging, intense, and ultimately as addictive as the human blood drained by the lead characters.<br /><br />\\"The Vampire Diaries\\" tells the story of Elena Gilbert (Nina Dobrev), a serious and strong-willed girl who has just lived through personal tragedy and is trying to wake back up to the real world in the small, mysterious town of Mystic Falls, Virginia. Elena's life is quickly and irrevocably complicated by the arrival of two brothers in her life: Stefan and Damon Salvatore (Paul Wesley and Ian Somerhalder, respectively), two young men of wildly different temperament, both attractive, both somewhat unhealthily interested in her...and both vampires.<br /><br />As Elena is entangled in a web of increasingly dangerous dark side mythology, she finds that the world around her is not what she knew as the bloody and fascinating history of Mystic Falls begins to come alive around her, leading to shocking revelations and violent twists. As Elena learns of her and her friends' connections to the bloody vampiric past, a mysterious new history teacher (Matt Davis) with a hidden past has the power to shed shocking light on Elena's past, leaving viewers breathless for each new episode and ending the season on an explosive cliffhanger so tense it leaves viewers' hearts pounding in fear and excitement in equal turns.<br /><br />\\"The Vampire Diaries\\" succeeds, first and foremost, on the strength of its characters. Elena is a grave young girl who has a fiercely strong core. She is unafraid to stand up for what she believes in, and it is her iron will that guides her through her dealings with the Salvatore brothers. She is never weak or overwhelmed when dealing with Stefan's vampire nature -- she falls in love with Stefan *despite* the fact that he is a vampire, rather than because of it. It is the strength of her heart that breaks through to the human buried beneath the darker Damon, though the consequences of that awakening may be more brutal than Elena had counted on.<br /><br />Stefan is a delightfully nuanced character, at once taking some cues from \\"Angel\\" but retaining a new energy. Stefan's struggles with both his way of life and his dealings with Damon are intensely real. And as for Damon? How long has it been since we've seen television vampires who take genuine glee in their immortality? As the body count stacks up at Damon's feet, he is at turns hilariously over-the-top and terrifyingly evil. It's always unsettling to see the youthful and beautiful faces of the vampires change at a moment's notice to a twisted, ugly and veiny countenance.<br /><br />\\"The Vampire Diaries\\" also hosts a truly fascinating cast of secondary characters who each has their own story to tell: Elena's younger brother Jeremy (Steven R. McQueen), a brooding presence whose unhealthy ways of dealing with grief are intensely empathetic; Elena's best friend Bonnie (Katerina Graham), who discovers that she is a powerful witch and as directly linked to Mystic Falls' nightmarish past as Elena herself; Caroline (Candice Accola), a strong-willed girl who hides her strength behind her personality; Matt (Zach Roerig), Elena's ex-flame who fires the screen with his brooding presence; and many more distinct and sometimes mysterious inhabitants of the strange town of Mystic Falls. The setting itself is so realistic and so integral to the story that it almost becomes a character in and of itself, speaking to the quality of the writing.<br /><br />The series deals with teenage issues in an adult manner, never condescending to its audience by opening up to viewers of all ages. The vampires of the show have moments of real horror, reminding viewers that any creature that has to drink the blood of the living in order to survive is not to be trusted; there is enough fierce action and slight gore to keep viewers engaged while the romantic elements of the plot simmer with tension so tight that the explosions of passion are nearly as violent as the fight scenes themselves.<br /><br />\\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is a fun, fresh, and sharply-written supernatural drama that is sure to attract a strong fanbase. It certainly doesn't hurt that all of the actors are both attractive and talented and that the history of the town is as engaging as its present. Ultimately, \\"TVD\\" is a strong, bloodthirsty and fast-paced ride, and it just may be enough to prove to the world that the vampire genre still has plenty of bite left in it yet.<br /><br />5 out of 5 stars.<br /><br />NOTE: \\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is based on the series of novels of the same name by teenage author of the '90's, LJ Smith; however, the show deviates strongly from the novels in many positive ways -- no longer is Elena a shallow blonde beauty queen; no longer is Stefan an overbearing, brooding bore, no longer is Damon a callow and irritating bad guy. While fans of the book series may take issue with the differences between the novels and the series, non-fans and those who have never read the novels are certainly not missing much by watching the show rather than reading the books.iewers engaged while the romantic elements of the plot simmer with tension so tight that the explosions of passion are nearly as violent as the fight scenes themselves.    \\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is a fun, fresh, and sharply-written supernatural drama that is sure to attract a strong fanbase. It certainly doesn't hurt that all of the actors are both attractive and talented and that the history of the town is as engaging as its present. Ultimately, \\"TVD\\" is a strong, bloodthirsty and fast-paced ride, and it just may be enough to prove to the world that the vampire genre still has plenty of bite left in it yet.    5 out of 5 stars.    NOTE: \\"The Vampire Diaries\\" is based on the series of novels of the same name by teenage author of the '90's, LJ Smith; however, the show deviates strongly from the novels in many positive ways -- no longer is Elena a shallow blonde beauty queen; no longer is Stefan an overbearing, brooding bore, no longer is Damon a callow and irritating bad guy. While fans of the book series may take issue with the differences between the novels and the series, non-fans and those who have never read the novels are certainly not missing much by watching the show rather than reading the books.
B000LPS47U|5.0|Few films hold such a huge cult following and incredible camp value as Stuart Gordon's RE-ANIMATOR. Jeffrey Combs stars as the petulant Dr. Herbert West, a man obsessed with restoring brain and muscle activity in recently deceased bodies. After unlocking the secret re-agent needed to bring back the dead, West is blindsided by a greedy professor that intends on claiming the discovery as his own, and it is up to he and a fellow student to stop a group of undead corpses that are resurrected as a result of the misuse of his formula. Combs is iconic in this, his most memorable role. His manic behavior is contrasted by Bruce Abbott's timid performance as Dan Cain, the voice of reason behind West's brilliant insanity. RE-ANIMATOR is filled with bloody gore and gratuitous nudity (care of genre favorite Barbara Crampton), setting the bar for countless films to follow and defining what 80s Horror was all about. Dennis Paoli's dark script adds a wicked humor to H.P. Lovecraft's original short, which is grown organically out of the absurd situations rather than cheap gags or slapstick. The greatest of these moments involve David Gale as Dr. Hill's disembodied head as he commands his bumbling body to assist him in his nefarious schemes. Many of the FX may seem silly to younger audiences that have been spoiled by the countless advances in make-up design and computer imaging, but the prosthetic work and creative framing used in RE-ANIMATOR are clever low-cost techniques that were both effective and ground-breaking for the time. Stuart Gordon's breakthrough hit is an unmistakable Horror classic that is just as hilarious and entertaining today as it was 25 years ago, and is a must-own for every genre fan.<br /><br />-Carl Manes<br />I Like Horror Movies
B002ZG98VE|5.0|The story of Robin Hood has been told in films with different plot twists. In Douglas Fairbanks' version from 1922, Robin Hood is the Earl of Huntington, going off on Crusade with King Richard (played by Wallace Berry).  Huntington returns to oppose Prince John, who is threatening to take the throne from his brother.     Errol Flynn's version has Robin Hood staying in England as a Saxon nobleman opposing Prince John for the same reasons as Douglas Fairbanks' Huntington.  Kevin Costner keeps the Third Crusade in the story but adds a Muslim warrior played by Morgan Freeman.  There are many approaches to telling the story of Robin Hood.     Ridley Scott's version is perhaps the most ambitious.  The film begins with Richard the Lion Heart's siege of the Castle Chaulus Chabral in Normandy.  This is where we meet Robin Longstride, a skilled archer, who has followed King Richard into battle for many years.  The king looks for an honest man and is confronted with Longstride who has been running a game of chance and is accused (by Little John) of cheating.  Robin is not cheating but, ironically, his honest answers to the king land him and his companions shackled.  So much for honesty and kings.     The death of King Richard allows Robin and his companions to escape and flee back home.  Along the way, they run across a party led by Robert Loxley retuning the crown back to England.   Loxley has been attacked by an English nobleman named Godfrey (magnificently played by Mark Strong) who is conspiring with King Philip of France to invade England.  Loxley is mortally wounded but Robin and his companions rout Godfrey and his men.  The dying Loxley asks Robin to return his sword to his father.  Not being a nobleman, Robin impersonates Loxley and returns the crown to the hands to Prince John.     The story develops with Robin and his men going to Nottingham where Robin is, conveniently, asked by Sir Walter Loxley (Max von Sydow) to pretend to be his son in order to preserve the household for his daughter-in-law Marion (Cate Blanchett).  The story centers on stopping Godfry and the intended invasion of England by King Philip.  A sub-plot concerns the rights of Englishmen centered on a documents of rights that Robin's father (long ago executed) was instrumental in conceiving. The document is the Magna Carta in all but name.     This Robin Hood brings the 12th century to life in all of its grim realities of hard work and, by our standards, hard living.  The production design is beautifully conceived, down to the rushes strewn on the floor of the manor house.  The performances are magnificent down to supporting roles. It was nice to see Mark Addy (of The Full Monty) as Friar Tuck and Oscar Isaac made an effective quarrelsome King John.  John Hurt has a strong role as William Marshall, a courtier of King Richard, and Eileen Atkins made a strong Queen Eleanor.  Danny Huston made an exciting Richard the Lion Heart.     The film ends with Robin declared an outlaw for supporting the rights of Englishmen.  The film ends where Errol Flynn's version begins.  I have not heard if Ridley Scott intends to take up the story but we are left in anticipation of what is to come.  This Robin Hood is well acted and beautifully photographed. The story is refreshingly different from the other Robin Hood's but it is a story that has differed from film to film and television.
B001JDS7CU|5.0|bought the regular version - had to have the Blue-Ray version.  I was not disappointed!  Tremendous body of work and enjoy it every time.  never get tired of seeing it again and again

And although I loved Twilight, I actually have enjoyed this series much more.  Can't wait for season two to begin!
B002JVWR4A|5.0|At the beginning of the fifth season of the wildly popular forensic drama \\"Bones,\\" many viewers tuned in trepidatiously after the spectacularly strange fourth season finale. Thankfully, all fears were allayed and relieved when the fifth season kicked into high gear in the very first episode and maintained that pace throughout the season; \\"Bones\\"' fifth season is perhaps its greatest yet.<br /><br />The one thing that has always set \\"Bones\\" apart from the countless other procedurals on the airwaves right now is the focus on the characters solving the crimes rather than the crimes themselves, and the strength of this approach shines through brilliantly in every episode of this season.<br /><br />David Boreanaz and Emily Deschanel return to the roles of Booth and Bones and deliver their strongest performances yet as each character is shaken to their core. As Booth struggles to regain his sense of self, he has to confront the knowledge of his feelings for his partner, while Bones herself goes through a whirlwind of emotion as the emotional barriers she has erected around her heart begin to crumble down, leaving her questioning not only herself but her relationship with Booth as well as her work at the Jeffersonian itself. The tension between the two has never been more delicious or more addictive, and both lead actors knock their roles absolutely out of the park.<br /><br />But while the relationship between Booth and Brennan becomes increasingly more complex, the wonderful supporting cast of engaging characters at the Jeffersonian keep the show moving along briskly and lightly. Cam (Tamara Taylor) must run the lab while dealing with the challenge of being a good mother, guiding the team effectively toward each conclusion; Sweets (John Francis Daley) continues to provide invaluable insight into the minds of the team; Angela (Michaela Conlin) remains the emotional heart and soul of the team as she opens her heart to love's possibilities; and Hodgins (TJ Thyne) struggles with his feelings for Angela as he returns to his abrasive, loveable self.<br /><br />The cases themselves have regained a fascinating light as the mysteries the team confronts become more complex, and the special effects department has outdone themselves in the gore and goop department this year as Booth and Bones investigate some of the most gruesome crime scenes in history, all moved along by the brisk black humor the show excels at; the team investigates a possible secret agent locked in a truck for days, a would-be rocker torn to pieces by an industrial washer/dryer, a gamer literally melted in a vat of fast-food grease, and a dozen more cheerfully disgusting cases where the outcomes of the mysteries hold the power to shock and surprise the audience; the writers have once again caught the perfect balance between the whodunnit and the drama to craft a truly unique show.<br /><br />But it's not merely the cases that hold the viewers' attention this season; season five is full of true powerhouse episodes: heartbreaking cases like \\"The Plain in the Prodigy\\"; darkly comical shows like \\"The Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood\\"; truly shocking mysteries like \\"The Proof in the Pudding,\\"; and even a historically fascinating case written by the author of the original Temperance Brennan novels Kathy Reichs herself (\\"The Witch in the Wardrobe\\") -- however, all of these merely lead up to the three knockout moments of the season:<br /><br />In the fifth season, \\"Bones\\" reaches its 100th episode, \\"The Parts in the Sum of the Whole.\\" Likely the most beloved and most contested episode in the show's history, the 100th episode completely redefined Booth and Brennan's relationship as it showed the viewers the pair's first meeting, something never before revealed, and circles around to one of the most hearbreaking and yet most powerfully hopeful moments of the series. \\"Parts\\" was also directed by David Boreanaz, one of the series' leads, and the sheer emotion wrung out of Boreanaz and Deschanel by the end speaks volumes to the talent of the show's leads.<br /><br />As the series continues, however, the characters were shocked to their cores as they were forced to come face-to-face with their most terrifying adversary yet: the cunningly frightening sociopath dubbed The Gravedigger, in \\"The Boy with the Answer,\\" a nail-bitingly tense hour of television that had viewers' hearts pounding as Heather Taffet, the Gravedigger, proved that her true arena was the courtroom, tearing apart her victims and throwing the entire future of Brennan's life into question.<br /><br />This only segues into the season's amazingly dramatic finale, \\"The Beginning in the End.\\" As the team investigates the home of a hoarder, Bones questions what she truly wants to do with her life, Booth's past comes calling, and Angela's father blows back into town, all leading to a truly shocking season ender, a masterful finale that not only redefined the very foundations of the show and the characters but also contined to set the show on a rising point, ensuring that every faithful viewer of \\"Bones\\" will be frantically waiting for the sixth season to premiere in the fall.<br /><br />In the past five years, \\"Bones\\" has redefined the procedural while producing a truly unique show filled with drama, comedy and the most satisfying romantic tension between two characters in years. Featuring challenging cases, intriguing mysteries, gruesome discoveries, fascinating character interactions, and truly touching and shocking turns in the lives of a cast of characters an increasingly growing fanbase have come to know and genuinely care about, \\"Bones\\" has proven that it still has plenty of tricks to show, and this wonderfully strong drama will remain on television for seasons to come.<br /><br />Five out of five stars.<br /><br />NOTE: The fifth season also features the return of Max (Ryan O'Neil), Brennan's father, as well as a memorable cameo by Zooey Deschanel (Emily's real-life sister) as Brennan's zany cousin, as well as a truly touching show introducing Booth's grandfather, as well as the return of Jared Booth (Brendan Fehr), Seeley's younger brother, who has some news of his own.<br /><br />Also, it is important to note that in the fifth season, the writers managed to fix a truly annoying plot device: the revolving interns, who alternated between odd and downright annoying throughout the fourth season, have now managed to find a balance and a home on the show, with each character's unique traits adding to the episode they are featured in, providing some much-needed comic relief as well as some unexpected drama along the way.ent of the show's leads. This only segues into the season's amazingly dramatic finale, \\"The Beginning in the End.\\" As the team investigates the home of a hoarder, Bones questions what she truly wants to do with her life, Booth's past comes calling, and Angela's father blows back into town, all leading to a truly shocking season ender, a masterful finale that not only redefined the very foundations of the show and the characters but also contined to set the show on a rising point, ensuring that every faithful viewer of \\"Bones\\" will be frantically waiting for the sixth season to premiere in the fall. B000001EAQ|4.0|A lot of U2 fans seem to dismiss this album as one of the band's weaker efforts, but I really get a lot of significant enjoyment out of it.  Although it is often branded as \\"techno\\" I don't really see this as a techno record at all.  Yes, there are some elements here, but this is still U2 albeit with a somewhat different sound to them.  Commercially this album did not do nearly as well as most of the band's other releases, but to my ears it is full of solid tunes.  Highlights include \\"Discotheque\\", \\"Mofo\\", \\"Last Night On Earth\\", \\"Staring At The Sun\\", \\"Playboy Mansion\\" and \\"Wake Up Deadman\\".  The only real weak track on the disc is \\"Miami\\" and even that one has grown on me over time. Here's the web address where you can read that review: [...]    But the movie is definitely worth watching, not only because it's sort of required watching for any film fan in the way that Moby Dick, however hard it is to get through the chapters on Cetology, is required reading (justly or not) for any American who considers themselves literate, but also because there is a truly epic, and highly intriguing story that is the film itself.  Welles and Hearst are great characters in themselves, fuller, more complicated and more absurd than any character in the film, and all of the hoopla surrounding the film and those characters as well as others (like Welles' \\"co\\"-screenwriter Herman Mankiewicz)are definitely worth looking into.  In fact there are two very good films all about it, [[ASIN:B0000507OD The Battle Over Citizen Kane]] and [[ASIN:0783116764 RKO 281 - The Battle Over Citizen Kane]] a nonfiction and fiction account, respectively.  So the film Citizen Kane serves as starting point for one of America's great stories, and for that reason I recommend it.

0061703257|5.0|\\"Shutter Island\\" follows two US Marshals tasked with finding an escaped patient at a mental hospital for the criminally insane on an island. She left the cell in the night seemingly into thin air. As the Marshals investigate further they realise they're not being told the truth by anyone on the island; the doctors, the orderlies, the nurses are all lying to them. Then they discover messages left by the patient which leads them to discover the true nature of the island and its' inhabitants.<br /><br />The novel is told at a blistering pace. The plot develops quickly, the twists come out of nowhere and it's a genuinely thrilling read. Lehane has an amazing grasp of atmosphere filling this book in spades. From the damp cells to the eerie staff quarters inside the odd fort to the mysterious lighthouse, there's so much here that's perfectly placed that it kept me reading much longer and quicker than I thought I would whenever I picked it up.<br /><br />There are a few people who don't like the ending but who reads a novel for the last 20-30 pages? It's a 325 page book - enjoy the journey! And I liked the ending anyway. It was far-fetched but given the nature of the institution you have to say that it's at least plausible.<br /><br />\\"Shutter Island\\" is well written, imaginative (how many novels really have that quality?), it's genuinely interesting and I loved it. This was my first Dennis Lehane novel and I've already got others lined up ready and can't wait. Highly recommended.

0439023483|5.0|THE HUNGER GAMES, by Suzanne Collins, was a fantastic and thrilling story of survival when all odds are against you. I almost wanted to know more about these children before their untimely and unnecessary deaths. Katniss was an amazing choice as the POV. She was selfless and strong, and all she wanted was to support her family. But she ended up with the short end of the stick when she volunteered to take her sister's place in the Hunger Games. In the beginning, Katniss would do anything but conform to the rules of the Capitol, but she quickly learned that to survive in the Hunger Games she would need to put on a facade or she would not live. She did manage to stay true and honest to herself, which ended her in a precarious situation at the end.     The men in this book were so great. Gale, as Katniss' best friend and partner, was a strong and perfect gentleman and an obvious choice for Katniss. But Peeta, being thrust into the Hunger Games with Katniss, created another piece of the triangle that was equally tempting.    I was blown away by this book. The idea of the Hunger Games was inhumane and disturbing. The fact that this government went to such great lengths to punish the children of those who rebelled stirred powerful and hateful emotion in me while reading. I do appreciate the honesty and amazing creativity that Collins put into this book, and I cannot wait to continue this series.
B00192KCQ0|4.0|Let me preface this by saying I've been or had been a fan of Metallica since I was first introduced in the '80's - I wasn't even 10 years old yet. I had an older brother that, thankfully showed me some good metal music. Metallica was one such band. Their 80's releases were so solid (I ignore the song One due to the great guitar work on the rest of that release). Then that fateful day so many dispute. August 13th, 1991. I remember driving to the store at the mall waiting for the gates to open at the record store, getting in and grabbing the first copy to fly off their shelves, taking it home and playing it at headbanging volume... what? Where are the palm muted triplets? Where's James trademark aggression... who told him he could 'sing'? It was... Bob Rock, that bastard pulled the balls right off Metallica and stole our band from us. Sure, the self titled album won the band accolades and millions of new fans but something was missing, it was Flemming Rasmussen at the helm of production (he had been there up to the ST release) many people may not realize the importance of a producer that can bring out the best in the band. I don't feel Bob Rock did that for Metallica. He brought something out of them, just not the edge or grit that some of the fans (myself included) yearned for. I listened to the 'Black Album' as my friends and I started to call it, looking for songs I could get into, bang my then long hair to... they weren't there. I ended up selling off my Metallica stuff for about 40 bucks to a friends cousin who was just getting into them. I was done.   I happened to catch 'Some Kind of Monster' not too long ago. Watching it I had sadly realized what Bob Rock had done to the band and maybe, what they had done to themselves. But, after a while of watching this I had thought to myself they should get Rick Rubin to produce them... then after getting done watching it I went and previewed the songs from St.Anger... nope.   Then I checked out Death Magnetic and saw thatit was produced by Rick Rubin.. WHAT?! So I previewed the tracks again, they were growing on me and I had wrote Metallica OFF. After reading some questionable comments on the MP3 quality I went to my local used CD store and found a copy for a steal. Dropped it in the CD player and hit the road. What was this, nod worthy riffage? Less singing and more aggro? I'll admit I haven't gone over the lyrics line by line yet (I'm nervous). But I have to say RR brought out what has been missing for the last decade.     Metallica    On a techie side, do the drums seem slightly loud in the mix or is that just me? Honestly I'm happy to say that I can listen to this end to end with little skipping or FF over. I'm sorry I can't listen to 'Unforgiven' anything...     Let's hope when the band and Rick come together again in 2011 we get something of equal or better quality.

B000FBJAOG|4.0|\\"The Zombie Survival Guide\\" is a very enjoyable satire that will be enjoyed by most Zombie aficionados. Max Brooks (the son of Mel Brooks) has written this rather serious toned guide to preparing for the Zombie Apocalypse that we all know is coming. The humor of the book isn't the \\"laugh out loud\\" type, but rather in the absurdity of the work as whole, so if that isn't what you want you might be happier with [[ASIN:0984067809 Zombocalypse Now]] (which I also enjoyed).<br /><br />The zombies covered in this guide are the truly dead, that is the [[ASIN:B00000K3TO Night of the Living Dead]] shuffler type that can only be stopped by a head shot, not the messed up living human type like found in [[ASIN:B00005JMA8 28 Days Later (Widescreen Edition)]] and [[ASIN:B002WY65VU Zombieland]] that can be taken out like any other human. This is an important distinction as it makes a big difference in your choice of weapons for your zombie fighting arsenal. So, with that distinction made, adjust your expectations (and strategies) accordingly.<br /><br />Max takes us through the cause of the zombie condition, rates the risk classifications by breakout type, suggests strategies, and presents equipment lists to deal with all of the various threat levels. There is also a section on the history of zombie outbreaks as derived from archeological evidence through more modern accounts, which was enjoyable but I found to be the weakest chapter.<br /><br />Keeping in mind that this is an elaborate work of satire, there are some factual errors that might cause purists to take offense (like a reference to \\"Nanook of the North\\" dying of starvation when it was actually likely Tuberculosis) and the effectiveness and use of certain weapons against zombies.<br /><br />Overall, this is clever work that provides an amusing insight into the strategies needed to survive the coming Zombie Apocalypse.<br /><br />Recommended!<br /><br />CFH

B00001OH7V|5.0|\\"Heroes\\" is the second album of David Bowie's \\"Berlin Trilogy\\".  It was recorded in July and August of 1977 in a West Berlin studio 500 yards from the Berlin Wall, and released in October 1977.  The album's sound reflects Bowie's appreciation of German electronica pioneers Neu! and Kraftwerk, with each band recognized in a respective song title.  Bowie and Brian Eno collaborated on most songs, with Bowie writing all of the lyrics.  The album has an upbeat, rollicking start with \\"Beauty and the Beast\\" and \\"Joe the Lion\\".  The triumphant title track is perhaps Bowie's most acclaimed song, and this album version is longer and even better than the familiar single version.  The slower \\"Sons of the Silent Age\\" and \\"Black Out\\" follow.  The upbeat \\"V-2 Schneider\\" opens Side Two of the original LP.  Three mostly quiet, ambient instrumentals follow: \\"Sense of Doubt\\", \\"Moss Garden\\" and \\"Neukoln\\".  \\"The Secret Life of Arabia\\" is the lighthearted closer, for which guitarist Carlos Alomar shares in songwriting credit.

B00005K9LN|5.0|Judas Priest are metal gods, they forever changed rock/metal music and for the better, they are an incredible band that continues touring and recording music even today. After the complex brand of rock'n'roll Judas Priest was doing during the 70's there seemed like they couldn't expend much further on this sound and therefore the band decided to go a simpler way with the arrival of the 1980's. There's no problem with the sound of British Steel at all, sure it's less complex than \\"Stained Class\\" for example and I must say that the blues elements are gone as well but it's still Judas Priest. The fact that Priest simplified their music doesn't mean they didn't have any creativity or great music left in them, as it turns out British Steel is one of the albums that really defined metal, is considered one the band's best albums and when the band is mentioned it is often for BS .<br /><br />British Steel has them all: heavy songs (Rapid Fire), classics (Metal Gods, Living After Midnight) pop-metal anthems (Breaking The Law) and radio staples (United). Honestly there is not a single bad song on this album, no fillers it's all good (even if some are better than others). The singles are excellent Priest but the rest of the album is equally as great if not more impressive. The 2001 edition remasters series of Judas Priest albums features extra songs and this one is no different, it only has two of them \\"Grinder (live)\\" from the Defender of the Faith tour and \\"Red White And Blue\\" from the Turbo sessions. The unfortunate thing is that those two songs aren't from the era of BS, there is nothing extra from the album's sessions or even the tour supporting the album but two extra songs is two extra songs so I'll take them.<br /><br />Although this is not my favorite Priest album I'm going to have to go with the majority and rate British Steel 5 stars, it really deserves it. It was my introduction to Judas Priest and I'm sure it was for many other fans. Classic album, greats songs, great musicianship and I could go on. If this is not in your rock/metal collection then let me tell you that there is a huge hole in your collection! It's an essential classic.p and I could go on. If this is not in your rock/metal collection then let me tell you that there is a huge hole in your collection! It's an essential classic.

The writing is so full of sentence fragments, repetition, poor phrasing, and cliche that I wonder how the author ever made it through middle school, let alone college.  Take pages 59 and 61 (of the hardback edition) for instance:    Page 59:  \\"In fact, if you really want to be confused, look up the words 'asset' and 'liability' in the dictionary.  I know the definition may sound good to a trained accountant, but for the average person it makes no sense.\\"    Page 61:  \\"If you want a lesson in confusion, simply look up the words 'asset' and 'liability' in the dictionary.  Now it may make sense to trained accountants, but to the average person, it may as well be written in Mandarin.\\"    Did he even proofread his manuscript before submitting it?    The content is as disappointing as the writing.  The author's point thus far is that by resisting dependence on a paycheck, one stimulates his imagination to acquire outside sources of income.  You can only attain wealth when your income from sources outside your paycheck is equal or greater to your expenses.  That's fine as far as it goes, but I'm a bit non-plussed that he took nearly half the book to say it.      He also stresses the importance of financial intelligence, and mentions in conjunction that it is unwise to run up credit card debt and increase your expenditures when your paycheck increases, but those points are fairly self-evident.      The author's negative views toward education bother me as well.  He seems to believe that people view formal education only as a means to get a high-paying job, and that since education does not always succeed in guaranteeing that high income, it doesn't have as much value as, say, focusing study on the way money works.  Although a college degree is often necessary to procure a high-paying job, the point of going to college is to learn.  Without a knowledge of history and literature, we wouldn't know who we were or where we came from or how to avoid the mistakes and repeat the triumphs of the past.  Without a knowledge of science and mathematics, we wouldn't understand (as much as we can understand) the natural world and universe around us.  Without the study of foreign countries and languages, we would never learn about cultures and ideas outside our own.  Relegating college to a resume-builder is insulting and shows a lack of appreciation for knowledge outside of the financial world.    I'll finish \\"Rich Dad Poor Dad\\" to satisfy the person who recommended it, but I do hope the second half is better than the first.  So far, reading it has been an utter waste of time.
B00275EGX8|1.0|I don't think I'm being unreasonable in expecting a war movie to aim for epic, not a dainty, benign slice-of-life. It's worth noting that (in stark contrast to Private Ryan), many soldiers find this movie unrelatable, and in many cases, slightly offensive. Its tone, and unwillingness to go far beyond \\"Army Wives\\" style sentiment (\\"War is dangerous and hard. Some soldiers like violence\\"), is put to shame by anyone who has viewed the 2007 wikileaks video.<br /><br />Were it not for the Academy's desire to put a stick to Cameron's eye, and Voltage Pictures' subsequent decision to sue thousands of Americans for viewing this movie, the Hurt Locker would quickly reach its sell-by date and rarely be mentioned again.

B002VPE1AW|1.0|The only thing amazing about Avatar is the obscene amount of money involved in its production, media hype and resulting sales for what you would imagine a schizophrenic would experience having a stroke in a fish aquarium.  Also amazing is my overwhelming shame for having sat through most of it, and the impression of having been mentally and visually violated afterward.     The plot is stupid. It is beyond stupid. It is insultingly stupid.  There is nothing subtle about it (or anything else in the film, for that matter), and it is as if it were written like background noise for what is amounts to a a grand-Mal seizure of special effects (I will get to that soon).    The plot is so asinine it is almost amusing, but it is not. It uses every single overdone cliche and crams it into what might end up being one of the most intellectually vapid story lines of all time. The evil humans are after a valuable mineral called \\"unobtanium\\" (Yes...that is actually what it is called.) and the only thing standing in their way is a special effects crew on massive amounts of LSD, and obviously black people, who have turned blue, grown tails and interact with the local wildlife by mounting the enraged beasts back, wrestling with it and then shoving a tubular part of their body containing a cluster of nerves forcefully into the animal. I understand it is the future, but I know that sort of behavior is generally frowned upon and can lead to some serious prison time.     The \\"natives\\" are stereotypically black mixed in with some American Indian.  Their accents are Jamaican, they wear loincloths and actually chuck spears. Yes, they chuck spears and the humans (all white) call them blue monkeys. I am almost shocked at how blatant it was. When I say almost, it is clear that the dialogue and plot were conceived and written in approximately 20 minutes, probably during a particularly painful bowel movement. A lot of money could have been saved had they just put the actors in blackface, handed them spears and made them worship watermelons.    I would also like to just throw out the weird Marines vrs Navy thing going on. The blue monkey people are called Na'Vi and symbolically sodomize animals and are thin and effeminate, while the marines are stupid and insane and have superior firepower. Maybe this was unintentional, however with a dad who was navy and a brother who was marines it seemed pretty obvious. Maybe Cameron was army?  And this is the last thing I will say about the plot.  (I won't \\"spoil\\" it...I mean if this is your first movie ever and you have never read anything more complicated than street sign you might be in for a treat.)   I watched this with my mom and her husband (they had already seen it). I went home around 20-30 minutes before it was over, even though my mother protested that it was almost over and the ending had a decent twist. On the way home I called my mother from my car and told her that I wanted to guess what happened. I summed up the ending and got every single detail correct except for the fate of one uninteresting character who was no longer relevant after the first part of the film.   Yes, you read that right. I did not watch the end of Avatar and I still knew exactly how it ended.    And now I am going to complain about the special effects. This will not take long. I have a theory. The technology used to take the acting out of live-action film was reminiscent of old CGI technology. Jurassic Park still looks better than the blue monkeys in Avatar. While the body movements were slightly more natural, even that detail was completely swallowed up by the amount of camera shake and computer animation that made the whole film. In fact, just the absolutely ridiculous amount of special effects in every single frame struck me as though Cameron was desperate to draw attention away from his own megalomaniac egos premature-ejacula.... it also made me wish I had brought a barf bag. While it had many beautiful scenes, they were so overdone and busy, the camera angles so unnatural and the panning and shake so fast, the only way to adapt without becoming dizzy and sick is to find the stationary point on the screen and stare at it. And the novelty of absolutely everything on the planet glowing, floating and sparkling wore off really fast. The only useful application I could see for this movie would be to fast-forward it and give neurologists a cheap way to detect epilepsy.     So the movie was awful, the plot was embarrassing and the only special effect I got from watching it was nausea. The worst thing about it is that for all the ungodly amounts of money that were dumped into that movie to make it special and fantastic, it was about as much fun as being beaten to death with glow sticks.  I chose to drive home at night and was scooping poo out of a cat box by the time my mom had finished Avatar.

B000E1ZBGS|2.0|I purchased this on a friend's recommendation, but I wish I had read more of the reviews first. An earlier reviewer described this as P&P as written by Charlotte Bronte and that about sums it up. Austen's sly social commentary and witty observations on human nature have been replaced by atmospheric shots of rain-drenched, fog-filled gloom and wavering shadows in candle-lit rooms. Elizabeth comes across as shrewish and broody, with none of the vivacity and quick wit of the original. Darcy seems dull and socially backward instead of a man restrained by his own rigid view of propriety and his place in the social caste. The secondary cast get only one or two pertinent lines from the novel to establish their character and motives, which reduces the circumstances that drive the plot to a one-dimensional Cliff Notes version of P&P.

Dick, a seemingly no-miss setup that would allow for both kicky science fiction adventure and philosophical jabs at the nature of identity. B000005AYM|5.0|Neo-soul wouldn't have been the same without Erykah Badu's 1997 debut Baduizm. The Dallas native's mixture of 30's jazz (her phrasing is reminiscent of Billie Holiday's), 70's soul (Chaka Khan in particular), and 90's hip-hop along with her colorful headwraps and earth mother persona set her apart from the other artists of the day. This entire album has a summery, free flowing vibe that's perfect for relaxing to.<br /><br />I don't have the slightest clue what On & On is about, but I've loved it ever since the first time I heard it on the radio. The lyrics are offbeat with a nice tribute to The Color Purple in the video. \\"I was born under water/With 3 dollars and 6 dimes/Yeah, you may laugh/Cuz you did not do your math.\\" I love that line! She shares some \\"food for thought\\" courtesy of her Ganny (grandma) on Appletree. \\"See I picks my friends like I picks my fruit/My Ganny told me that when I was only a youth/I don't walk around trying to be what I'm not/I don't waste my time trying to get what you got/I work at pleasin' me/Cuz I can't please you and that's why I do what I do/My soul flies free like a willow tree/Doo wee, doo wee, doo wee!\\"<br /><br />The atmospheric chill of Otherside Of the Game finds a pregnant Erykah torn between leaving her drug hustling man or keeping the family together. \\"He gave me the life that I came to live/Gave me the song that I came to give/Pressure on me/But the seed had grown/I can't make it on my own/Summer came around and the flowers bloomed/He became the sun/I became the moon/Precious gifts that we both received/But could this be make believe?\\" It's one of my favs and I usually play it twice.<br /><br />A new man comes along to whisk her away, but Erykah knows \\"I'm alot of woman/But not enough to divide my pie\\" and tells him that maybe they can be together in the Next Lifetime. \\"Maybe we'll be butterflies,\\" she sighs wistfully. Afro is an improvised spoken word set about a cheating boyfriend getting caught. \\"Well, you said you were gonna take me to see Wu Tang, baby/So I braided my hair... You changed your mind and said we weren't goin'/But my mama saw you there, yes she did!\\" Quirky and fun.<br /><br />Erykah channels Nina Simone on the jazzy, piano led Certainly, scolding a man for trying to form a romantic relationship with her although she's made it clear she's not interested. \\"I was not looking for no love affair!/But now you wanna kiss me.\\" The Flipped It mix replaces the piano with smooth vibes and upgrades to a more hip-hop production. Both are excellent!<br /><br />Badu encourages a man to grasp all the luck he can find in winning her heart on the acid jazz trip 4 Leaf Clover, but gets her heart broken by the darker No Love. \\"How can we make love when you don't love me?\\" she asks. Although she wants out of the one sided relationship, she can't let go. \\"When I first met you/I could hardly see/But now I'm blind, for real/I wish you knew how to rescue me/From this misery!\\"<br /><br />The Phyllis Hyman dedicated Drama calls for everyone to \\"lift your hearts to God\\" and \\"teach your children wisdom\\" when struggling with the pain life brings. The undulating Sometimes deals with the confusion of a quickly deteriorating relationship. \\"Sometimes/I don't love you anymore/I'm in love with you/I think that I'm going mad... Can you tell me where/Oh where did the love go?\\"<br /><br />Short, sweet and straight to the point, Baduizm is a masterpiece from start to finish. You might not understand the meaning behind some of the lyrics at first listen (or a dozen), but the music takes you away. Listen.Wu Tang, baby/So I braided my hair... You changed your mind and said we weren't goin'/But my mama saw you there, yes she did!\\" Quirky and fun.     Erykah channels Nina Simone on the jazzy, piano led Certainly, scolding a man for trying to form a romantic relationship with her although she's made it clear she's not interested. \\"I was not looking for no love affair!/But now you wanna kiss me.\\" The Flipped It mix replaces the piano with smooth vibes and upgrades to a more hip-hop production. Both are excellent!     Badu encourages a man to grasp all the luck he can find in winning her heart on the acid jazz trip 4 Leaf Clover, but gets her heart broken by the darker No Love. \\"How can we make love when you don't love me?\\" she asks. Although she wants out of the one sided relationship, she can't let go. \\"When I first met you/I could hardly see/But now I'm blind, for real/I wish you knew how to rescue me/From this misery!\\"     The Phyllis Hyman dedicated Drama calls for everyone to \\"lift your hearts to God\\" and \\"teach your children wisdom\\" when struggling with the pain life brings. The undulating Sometimes deals with the confusion of a quickly deteriorating relationship. \\"Sometimes/I don't love you anymore/I'm in love with you/I think that I'm going mad... 0312330537|5.0|Shantaram is a truely great novel. It's not perfect - but nothing in this life is right? This book will take you to places you haven't been before - guaranteed. Roberts is a gifted writer despite being fairly egotistical and frequently reminding the reader he is an \\"artist\\", \\"intellectual\\", and a \\"philosopher\\" at the same time a super hard man that nobody but nobody messes with!     What I found interesting was that people who normally live a life like Roberts do not have the ability to write about it as Roberts does. Therefore for me, apart from being an amazing romantic roller coaster ride, it also showed me the inside of an underworld I could never have know about in any other way.     By the way, I notice some people here have said things like \\"a rambling 935 pages\\". I think that people who do not see much beauty around them, the emotionally defunct or people with not much going on upstairs would probably find this book \\"rambling\\"     But for all others I would say it's a MUST read. Even if you don't agree with what Roberts says sometimes - you can't deny the book for being truly original and wonderfully entertaining.

0307454541|4.0|This is a very interesting book, although it takes quite a bit of<br />time to ramp up and an equal amount of time to ramp down.  The<br />middle of the book is where all the fun lies.  There are two<br />protagonists in the book --- Michael Blomkvist and Lisbeth<br />Salander.  Michael is a journalist fighting to keep his name clear of<br />accusations and Lisbeth is the unlikely partner who helps him do so.<br />The first quarter of the book is devoted to Michael, with Lisbeth's<br />introduction playing a small part.  We find out that she is a ward of<br />the state, she is very smart (both street smart and book-smart), an<br />exceptional cracker who it seems can siphon off data from any laptop<br />at a moment's notice and uses encryption programs like PGP as if they<br />were child's play.  She is also a recluse and somewhat of a neurotic<br />personality who trusts only one man --- the gentleman hired by the<br />state to look after her interests.  Alas, he dies and is replaced by another<br />one with much less morals.  The manner by which Lisabeth neutralizes<br />the new gentleman is, ummm, shall we just say interesting.  In due course,<br />she hooks up with Michael Blomkvist and together they solve a 50-year<br />old serial killing spree, and in the process, clear Michael's name<br />and ensure that the magazine Michael founded continues to survive.<br /><br />So far, so good.  Now the nits.  I think the author takes some little,<br />but jarring, liberties with the reader's attention.  Two examples:<br />it seems highly unlikely that Lisabeth's boss would leave his office<br />unguarded for her to tool around in it at will (the author establishes<br />the bonafides of Dragan Armansky, Lisabeth's boss who runs the detective<br />agency where she is employed, in no less than 3-4 pages.)  Given the<br />rather impressive accomplishments of Mr. Armansky, it is not in character<br />for him to leave his office devoid of any counter-measures to detect<br />unwanted snooping.  Second, after Lisabeth and Michael escape from the<br />killer's lair, Lisabeth makes a great show of wiping her and Michael's<br />fingerprints off from the furniture and other paraphernalia they may<br />have touched.  What she did not do was to wipe away all the DNA<br />evidence in form of blood, hair, and mucus that had piled up.  Surely<br />someone as smart as Lisabeth should know the ramifications of a DNA<br />strand?<br /><br />In summary, it was an enjoyable book despite minor flaws.  I have been<br />to Stockholm once, so it was fun to see the familiar station and street<br />names.  This is the first in a series of three novels that the author<br />wrote shortly before his demise. B002ONC9NC|3.0|I just saw An Education last night after waiting until it came onto DVD and Oscar hype had subsided.  I enjoyed it and thought that it was pretty solid for the first 95% of the movie.  However, I can't give an unqualified recommendation.  Here are my general impressions:    (i) Acting   Carey Mulligan needs to go over to Sandra Bullock's place to retrieve her Oscar. The travesty of Bullock's win for The Blind Side over Ms. Mulligan's subtle and sad, yet vivacious and spirited performance has made me question my conception of the universe - There is simply no conceivable way that a just and loving God could allow such an outrage to his creation.  Mulligan is an absolute star, transitioning throughout the film from an obedient but questioning schoolgirl to a rebellious adventurer to a devastated young woman.  I believed every step and found myself throughout thinking \\"Yes, that is how a young woman in that situation would act.\\"  Her internal conflict between pain, stubborn pride, naivety, ambition, and rebellion are just wrenching.  I will say it now: Carey Mulligan is the finest actress of her generation, bar none.     Peter Sarsgaard was great, as usual.  I spoke with my mother after we both independently watched this movie.  She said that, based on his character in An Education, she would never be able to watch another film with him again.  His character was just so despicable that she could never again see him on screen without reawakening her disgust and loathing.  I wouldn't go as far as that, but thought it spoke volumes about the power of his performance.      There are other noteworthy performances:  Olivia Williams, Alfred Molina, and (an effective, but underutilized) Emma Thompson.  Finally, here is a sentence that won't be repeated soon: Rosamund Pike (the bad guy from Die Another Day) was pretty darn good too.    (ii) Story and Script     The plot and the dialogue were both good.  I have to admit that Nick Hornsby generally drives me a little crazy.   Among other works, I read High Fidelity and saw About a Boy and my impression has always been that he tries too hard to be hip and quirky and spends a lot of time trying to convince his readers/audience how cool he is.  It's an affliction of many authors of his generation (I think the medical term is Brett Easton Ellis Syndrome) and it drives me absolutely batty.  Surprisingly, he did dial it back for the most part in this one and, notwithstanding an unfortunate monologue near the end by Mr. Molina, limited the ham-handedness of much of the script.      The big problem that I had with the movie was that the last ten minutes of the movie really compromises the first ninety.  I will give you a SPOILER WARNING right here, though if you know anything about the movie, nothing here should be too big a revelation.  The major theme of the movie is a clever, but sheltered young woman gets mixed up with an older man, who despite his surface sophistication, turns out to be not only a conman, but also much more sinister.  The progression of the story is how this girl is drawn step by step into his web while rejecting the premises that have driven her life up to their meeting.  The real narrative force of the movie is the battle between her beliefs in received values (i.e. ambition and independence) and her need to venture beyond the limits prescribed by her life, her family, and, indeed, by her society.  Her intellect heightens both sides of this conflict, justifying her ambitions while simultaneously amplifying the rebellion against them.  In the long run, her pride wins out to disastrous consequence, leaving her cheated of the fruits of either.  If the movie had ended there, it would have been a devastating, poignant story.   However, the actual end of the movie (actually really the last five to ten minutes), turns the whole conflict on its head.      (iii) The End  Instead of having paid the consequences for her choice, it turns out that, oh well, everything turns out peaches regardless.   It brought two thoughts to mind:    First, there is an episode of the show, \\"The Simpsons\\" where all the schoolchildren get stuck on an island and spend the episode trying to find a way to survive and form a society (yes, it was take-off of Lord of the Flies).  They struggle and fight and look for a way home to no avail.  Right as the show is ending with the children still stuck on the island, the narrator says, \\"Oh, yeah.... The children were rescued by, let's say, Moe\\".  The irony being that everything up to that point was pointless... Just wrap the thing up however.      Second, I have this visualization of some seedy Hollywood producer taking a look at an early cut and spitting out a profanity-laced tirade: \\"Don't you know chicks are going to see this and that chicks hate sad endings?   I don't want you coming back until you frou-frou up the ending, got it?  This is going to be my biggest hit since The Scarlet Letter.\\"*      The point being that any kind of emotional investment that you have in this character and this story (and for me it was good deal) is just undermined by this trite ending.  Why did it matter which road she took throughout the rest of the movie if they all led to the same place?  Why should a viewer care about the betrayal that was meticulously built throughout the rest of the movie if there are really no consequences anyway?  It just seemed lazy and pandering to me and made me sorry that I had taken the rest of the movie seriously.    Conclusion  Notwithstanding the three stars, I would recommend this movie if for nothing else for the acting.  However, I would warn against taking the plot too seriously; you will just be betrayed.      *As a personal note, I've never forgiven Gary Oldman for that one.

B000FVQLQQ|4.0|As a person living with mental illness, I would recommend the movie \\"A Beautiful Mind\\". The film was about a man's ascension in the mathematical community, descent into his own world of paranoid schizophrenia, and ultimate heroic accomplishments while accepting his symptoms and being able to disengage himself from his delusions and hallucinations. John Nash, the movies' main character, proves he is sophisticated as well as a brave man in his quest to overcome his symptoms of mental illness while struggling to make a name for himself among collegiate peers that were considered the elite of this country's great minds. This movie also demonstrated a historical perspective in respect to therapeutic measures of the past treatment of schizophrenia. The family structure demonstrated in the movie provided an accurate and sophisticated viewpoint of how families of the time period possessed ways and means for recovery. The role of the professional in regards to the psychiatrist provided insight into symptoms associated with schizophrenia in relation to educating both patient and their families. In conclusion, John Nash proved through his Beautiful Mind, that a person living with schizophrenia does not have to settle with the struggles of daily hallucinations and proved that he could achieve amongst the highest nobility of men.

The farm house is accidently bombed which sets off a series of events that involves a group, inside the Gestapo, that tricks wealthy Jews by offering them passage on a barge-like boat to liberated Belgium. 193413712X|5.0|There are a number of things that make this winner of the 2010 Pulitzer for Fiction remarkable:<br /><br />* Harding's prose here is exquisite. His voice is consistent, despite his giving life to a number of primary characters: George Crosby, first introduced in the book and dying of Parkinson's. Then George's father, Howard, a daydreamer who suffered epileptic seizures. And finally Howard's father, John, a Sunday sermonizer, as Howard termed John's gift. Harding's shifts between these men and their voices comes in an array of technical devices, voices, and points of view.  One in particular stands out as John is introduced:<br /><br />\\"It had never occurred to Howard to tell George about his own father. Howard thought to himself, That's right; my own father was always in the room upstairs...\\"<br /><br />* For a relatively young man, Harding demonstrates an awful lot of insight into the human condition:<br /><br />\\"George Crosby remembered many things as he died, but in an order he could not control...To look at his life...was to witness a shifting mass, the tiles of a mosaic, spinning, swirling, reportraying...showing him a different self every time he tried to make an assessment.\\"<br /><br />* His use of clocks as a recurring metaphor for time - the greatest onus a person might bear in life - is perhaps more tightly drawn than Orhan Pamuk's similar device in The Museum Of Innocence.<br /><br />* There's little story here (not my favorite thing) - simply vignettes that tend to summarize , not only George's life, but that of his heritage.<br /><br />* The book is largely a complex narrative (well executed, but again, not my thing), devoid of dialogue. What is offered as dialogue here is not put in quotes (another not-my-thing), which tends to subordinate the characters' various voices to that of the book's narrator. Taking this device on is a bit dangerous; one risks making the characters monochromatic and placing the narrator too obviously between text and reader. But Harding has a deft hand - he knows how to wring drops of voice from the scantiest dialogue bits without losing the narrative's consistency.<br /><br />* Harding's story is emotional - not by plot and character happenstance, but by tone and mood, by never surrendering the dignity of his characters to their many foibles. This is mastery of narrative, of the prose phenomenon we know as the novel.<br /><br />By my asides, you can tell my admiration for Tinkers is grudging. Harding has an MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop (MFAs having never been my thing), and this book is a case study in what's taught in those venues, those aspect hovering loosely about what we clumsily term post-moderism. But, ultimately, what makes Tinkers remarkable is that its author has the superb good taste to know when to use his technical tools and the talent to make the best use of them.<br /><br />Why did Tinkers win the Pulitzer? My guess: The book is a meditation on life's many limitations, but limitations that are never caricatured, never treated with banality, limitations that are marbled with humor and wonder and affirmation.<br />This is a dense book, not easily experienced by the casual reader - it will be worth multiple readings to plumb its essence in totality.<br /><br />My rating: 4-1/2 of 5 starss of voice from the scantiest dialogue bits without losing the narrative's consistency.     * Harding's story is emotional - not by plot and character happenstance, but by tone and mood, by never surrendering the dignity of his characters to their many foibles. This is mastery of narrative, of the prose phenomenon we know as the novel.    By my asides, you can tell my admiration for Tinkers is grudging. Harding has an MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop (MFAs having never been my thing), and this book is a case study in what's taught in those venues, those aspect hovering loosely about what we clumsily term post-moderism. But, ultimately, what makes Tinkers remarkable is that its author has the superb good taste to know when to use his technical tools and the talent to make the best use of them.     Why did Tinkers win the Pulitzer? My guess: The book is a meditation on life's many limitations, but limitations that are never caricatured, never treated with banality, limitations that are marbled with humor and wonder and affirmation.   This is a dense book, not easily experienced by the casual reader - it will be worth multiple readings to plumb its essence in totality.       My rating: 4-1/2 of 5 stars
B000024E9F|4.0|Not that there's anything wrong with music that can send you to sleep. This is pleasant, gentle, delicate sounding music. If you do fall asleep, the last couple of minutes of the final track could wake you up again, as it sounds positively heavy metal! Quieter than their superior debut, it's nonetheless a pleasant listen. As with their debut, there was, once again, a song which had lyrics that were daggy...in this album's case, that song is \\"White mountain\\". Some albums that I've heard in the last year or so do a similar line in storybook lyrics, but do it better. E.g. Cream's \\"Pressed rat and warthog\\" as well as Malcolm McLaren's punk origin story on \\"The great rock'n'roll swindle\\" album. Both 'songs' seem pitched at a younger audience than Genesis' song here, but they have a greater charm about them.      Best songs (on second listen):      Dusk - 4:13 minute long. A pleasant track with delicate vocals and string instruments. Both carry a nice melody. As with their first album, there is a touch of the Bee Gees to the backing vocals. Some exotic instrument features on this...a zither, at a guess? Has tinny bell clinks, an organ, and a flute. Lyrics touch on relgious themes, at times. Perhaps this song comes closest to having a commercial pop sensibility. With more refining of it, a pretty, hymnal, commercial sounding song could have been achieved. I love Mika's \\"Happy ending\\" single...it's a great recent example of how a pop song can have a haunting beauty to it.    The knife - 8:55. Has a rock intro with rock guitar and organ sound (think Deep Purple type sound). Lyrics are sort of heavy metal territory...some Metallica songs aren't too far away in spirit from this song. The last minute and a half or so sees heavy metal rhythms introduced, with heavy beats and strumming.      The rest:      Looking for someone - 7:06. Intro is bluesy and soulful, with the lead guitar notes on the electric guitar. Drumming is busy in a solid way, but interesting. A nice keyboard melody appears later. Flute makes an appearance.    White mountain - 6:45. Delicate dual acoustic guitar note picking. A boy's own type song...about a wolf, or sung as if he was the wolf. Again, these type of lyrics have been done by heavy metal band Metallica. Not being from England, I'll have to assume that my use of the word \\"naff\\" is apt for the lyrics in this song...talk of kings etc. Wind instruments in this song have a mediaeval flavour to them. Lead guitar intro brings to mind AC/DC's Angus Young, for his technique and sound in \\"Thunderstruck\\"...some nimble fretwork, in other words.     Visions of angels - 6:50. Genteel, piano notes, dual lead guitar notes, keyboard. Has a stronger sound at other times, with the drums for instance. Not sure if this song was written before or after Australian singer Helen Reddy won a Grammy award, but in any case, lead singer Peter Gabriel refers to God as \\"She\\"...like Reddy did, in her accepting speech...saying that \\"She made all things possible\\" or some such.    Stagnation - 8:50. Genteel, delicate track re vocals and guitar note picking. Has a pipe organ sound or some such to it...could be a synthesiser. Sounds more like a rock song later on.        Recommendations:        Genesis: From Genesis to Revelation    King Crimson: In the court of the Crimson King/In the wake of Poseidon    Cream: Wheels of fire/Disraeli gears
B003BKF696|5.0|The National's music is hard to pin down.  It might be harder after listening to High Violet.  It is another example of what happens when an ever-maturing, ever-productive group of musicians is allowed to experiment with sounds and develop.  Each song features a distinctive layering of lyrics, the sound of each instrument, and showcases the abilities of everyone in the group.  High Violet demonstrates The National's commitment to a consistent, evoloving style true to their muscial roots.  They are fast becoming the defining American band of a generation.    This is an album that requires repeated listenings.  Given time, each song reveals something you didn't quite hear earlier.  The final three songs--Conversation 16, England, and Vanderlyle Crybaby Geeks--demonstrates the full range of their creativity.  Oboes in unexpected places.  Sing-a-long choruses.  Optimism not found in earlier recordings.  Just a great album.
B000002HPT|4.0|This is an excellent release although even the band derides it for many reasons, not least among them the undue pressure exerted on them by the record label to release something \\"commercial\\" vetoing a composition that the band had  created as a sequel to Metropolis Part One. Also, the label recruited hit guru Desmond Child which  helped the band  to commercialize at least one hit that I know, called you not me. The solo was abridged and the title of the song changed (it was called \\"You Or Me\\").  Even with all these problems it is a magnificent record. But you'd expect that from the Dream Theater pack right?

0385341008|5.0|A pleasant surprise and heart-warming story about a slice of history that might have been lost to the average reader of World War II tales. I had never heard of this small island of Guernsey and its German occupation, and was pleased with the author's efforts to personalize that time in history. I was surprised that the \\"re-telling\\" f the story through letters worked so well, and would encourage readers to give it a little while to get into. Also, while I know that the war was harrowing...this story is not as graphic as others set in  WWII, like Shindler's List, The Pianist, Sarah's Key, or Those Who Save Us.
